ygData.subject: RE: [archive-crawler] monitoring crawls
ygData.msgSnippet: In general, yes. I ve been managing a crawl of the entire .is TLD, and while most domains require no special attention, about 3-5% have various crawler traps.

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

In general, yes. I've been managing a crawl of the entire .is TLD, and whil=
e
most domains require no special attention, about 3-5% have various crawle=
r
traps. It should be noted here that the definition of a 'trap' may vary.
=
Some sites have very large messageboards which may be counted as 'traps' fo=
r
those not interested in them. We however wanted to get them, but we did n=
ot
want to get all the interactive options (reply to message etc).
 
So, ba=
sically, yes, you have to monitor a crawl, especially if you are
crawling a=
 website for the first time. Depending on your available bandwidth
and stor=
age space, you may need to do this very diligently, but in my case
it was g=
enerally enough to review the logs and reports each morning and make
any ne=
eded adjustment. Often, especially the morning after launching a
crawl, my =
actions would lead to crawler discarding 3/4 of the URIs queued.
 
However,=
 I also discovered several common traps, and applying that knowledge
I was =
able to crawl more efficiently as time went on. While this knowledge
will n=
ever be perfect (the is changing all the time) I do believe that it
will si=
gnificantly simplify the next round of crawling.
 
- Kris
 
P.s. For those =
interested, here are a few stats from the snapshot of the .is
web:
Number o=
f documents: 34 million, from just over 10000 domains.
Amount of data: 1.25=
 TB or 700 GB compressed
The largest single host had 431 thousand documents=
.
Crawled in ten segments, over a two month period using Heritrix 1.0.4

--=
---Original Message-----
From: robeger [mailto:reger@...] 
Sent: 3. d=
esember 2004 21:31
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [archive-cr=
awler] monitoring crawls



This is kind of a general crawl question, not s=
pecific to heritrix,
but I figured this was as good a place as any to ask i=
t.  Basically,
when you're running a crawl, does a person generally monitor=
 it, to
watch for it getting stuck on a site (calendars, etc) and make
adju=
stments, or do you have some kind of app that monitors it and
notifies some=
one?

I was just running a single site crawl to try some things with
settin=
gs and ended up having to add some filtering for it because it
had a forum =
message board and a calendar that was going to go on and
on.  This kind of =
thing would be hard to anticipate in advance (I
think) because sites are go=
ing to name pages different, implement
things different (php, html, etc.).
=

Rob
Aptas, Inc.
